Subject: Open Question Re: Significance of Composition of Generation Zero
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=281645563; y=EGqk1js0PmxZkGTp26dWHZk5D32m6wOywPA7toF_eLDXmw
X-Yahoo-Profile: afcarl2

Ken,

With all due respect,


> The idea that you might create many initial=
 populations and 
evaluate 
> all of them is not buying any obvious advanta=
ge because you still 
end 
> up having to evaluate all those initial popula=
tions.

I disagree. For standard NEAT params, test cases (the results summa=
ry 
of which has been included in prior postings) demonstrate that the 
pro=
duct of number of individuals times generations are not created 
equal. 


=
> Note that search efficiency is generally considered to be number of 
> ev=
aluations, so if 1,000 evaluations are added at the get-go, some 
> consequ=
ence would need to make up for that initial investment.


Specifically, for=
 a given number of evaulations (i.e. # individuals * 
generations), higher =
fitness was achieved when the composition 
included more "0 generation" eva=
luations rather than less.


> The answer is not obvious because the dynami=
cs of both strategies 
are 
> quite complex and domain-dependent.


Reasona=
bly so, but not an adequate justification to set-aside the 
issue. Until yo=
u actually implement code infrastructure to attempt to 
quantify such thing=
s as: a) exact genome duplication as measured by 
visitation of design poin=
ts, not just genome structure, b) effective 
genome duplication (i.e. so cl=
ose to be effectivily a duplicate), and 
c) coverage of the design space, y=
ou will not uncover just how 
redundant and limited coverage of the design =
space is for standard 
NEAT params for a given population size and number o=
f generations.

I am a huge fan of the NEAT method. But the method will not=
 achieve 
its potential to handle practical real-world problems until these=
 
profound inefficiencies are addressed.

The standard NEAT params appear t=
o be very conservative, resting on 
the benefits of the NEAT method itself =
to make up for the undue 
burden of their conservatisim. But that only goes=
 as far as the 
trivialness of the fitness function evaluation. After which=
 it sinks 
under the computational weight of its own inefficiency and 
cons=
ervatisism for practical problems where the fitness evaluation is 
non-triv=
al. It would be very disappointing that the benefits of the 
NEAT method ge=
t lost due to the failure to address the significance 
and adaptive control=
 potential characteristics of the NEAT params.

Dancing rag-dolls reveal ap=
plicability of the NEAT method to new and 
interesting areas, but there is =
more fundamental research required on 
the exploitation of the NEAT params =
before you will see the NEAT 
method commonly applied to practical real-wor=
ld problems, as it 
rightfully should/could be.

Hand waving over "complex =
and domain-dependent" is an inadequate 
justification for chosing to ignore=
 the issue, and instead focus on 
new and interesting areas in which the is=
sue is not addressed.

Andy Carl


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth St=
anley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> The distribution of the initial generation=
s indeed can affect the 
> course of evolution.  However, it is difficult t=
o make informed a 
> priori decisions about the initial population before a=
n experiment 
is 
> run, because little may be known about the structure of=
 the search 
> space.  However, I believe there has been work on the compos=
ition 
of 
> initial populations in GAs and the right random distribution (=
e.g. 
> uniform vs. normal, or something else) of individuals in that 
> po=
pulation to best cover the search space.  
> 
> The idea that you might cre=
ate many initial populations and 
evaluate 
> all of them is not buying any=
 obvious advantage because you still 
end 
> up having to evaluate all thos=
e initial populations.  For example, 
> let's say that the population size =
is 100.  Then if you generate 10 
> initial populations, you end up evaluat=
ing 1,000 individuals before 
> deciding in which population to invest furt=
her.  On the other hand, 
> if you start with simply one population, then a=
fter 1,000 
evaluatins 
> you will have proceeded 10 generations.  So the q=
uestion is, which 
> was more effective, evaluating 10 random populations, =
or evaluating 
> 10 generations of evolutionary search?  
> 
> The answer i=
s not obvious because the dynamics of both strategies 
are 
> quite complex=
 and domain-dependent.  One could argue for the 
> advantages of either.  H=
owever, what can be said is that there is 
no 
> knock-down reason that hav=
ing multiple initial populations will 
> improve efficiency.  
> 
> Note th=
at search efficiency is generally considered to be number of 
> evaluations=
, so if 1,000 evaluations are added at the get-go, some 
> consequence woul=
d need to make up for that initial investment. 
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@y=
ahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@> wrote:
> >
> > Is there any significanc=
e to the composition of generation zero 
> beyond 
> > that of providing a =
radomized evaluation/starting point of the 
> design 
> > space? If the com=
position is a set of random points in the design 
> > space, is one populat=
ion/set of random starting points any 
> different 
> > than any other, exc=
ept for perhaps getting lucky in regards to a 
> higher 
> > fitness potent=
ial via complexification?
> > 
> > The function of the NEAT params are focu=
sed on transition to 
> subsequent 
> > generations, and as such appear neu=
tral wrt generation zero, 
except 
> for 
> > perhaps population size.
> > =

> > If this is the case, is there any loss of generality by 
generating 
>=
 > multiple populations of generation zero, and cherry-picking the 
> best =
as 
> > the population to proceed with NEAT evolution?
> >
